post_text: Today is Founders Day at FACTS! It’s a day for celebrating the birthday of our school. We gathered as a school community to remember where we came from. Teacher Ellen shared, “FACTS is here because regular people, people you know, worked to create it…FACTS isn’t just this school building or the desks and chairs or the school buses coming and going every day. FACTS is the vision that we can make a school that will help the students become the leaders that our communities and our world need. Each of us make the dream of FACTS come true when we see something that isn’t fair, something that is hurtful, and we work to change it. We make the dream of FACTS come true when we listen respectfully to many points of view. We make the dream of FACTS come true when we are kind to each other and support each other as learners. When we do these things, we are becoming the leaders who make positive change the world. All of us are founders because we have to work hard every day to carry forward the dream of FACTS. Happy Founders Day!”

post_text: Each December, all FACTS students learn from and work with resident artist Teacher Losang as he creates a Tibetan Sand Mandala. Through this residency, students gain knowledge about the history, wisdom, and beauty of sand mandalas. Sand mandalas are complex pictures that tell stories and lessons about the ways that people can live good lives and how the universe can enjoy blessings such as peace, forgiveness, health, and prosperity. Students watch the mandala grow and then ultimately be dismantled and returned to the Earth.

post_text: Today at FACT Charter School, we continued our tradition of observing Many Points of View Day rather than celebrating Columbus Day. We opened our school assembly by singing, "Columbus sailed across the sea, but someone was already here." This year as we were singing, we reflected on the struggle of the Standing Rock Sioux. Teacher Lucinda reminded us that the peoples and cultures who were here before Columbus got here are still here. Tribes from across the continent are using their cultures and their knowledge from their ancestors to come together to save the land and protect the water.

Teacher Lucinda reminded us that the peoples and cultures who were here before Columbus got here are still here. Tribes from across the continent are using their cultures and their knowledge from their ancestors to come together to save the land and protect the water.

Folk Arts-Cultural Treasures Charter School

post_text: FACTS wishes everyone a Happy Lunar New Year and Year of the Sheep! For many of our students, families, and staff, the lunar new year is an important celebration of family and renewal. FACTS observes this holiday by taking time in our classrooms to discuss time-keeping practices and different new year celebrations, providing the new year day off to observe with families, and with an annual Lunar New Year Show. The show was a big hit with a variety of student performances: lion dance, parade of sheep, Vietnamese dan tranh, fan and ribbon dance, calligraphy demonstration, student emcees, rap, and more! As per our tradition, we ended with a whole school singing of 恭喜Gongxi. Thank you to the hardworking Lunar New Year Committee for putting on this amazing show and to Parkway Center City High School for hosting our show. Chúc mừng năm mới! Feliz año nuevo! post_text: If you looked to the sky today around 12:45pm, you would have seen a message: "scientia 正义 it takes a village". FACTS teachers T. Kao, T. Rana, and T. Annie with Roman Catholic High School staff worked together to come up with part of a message for Asian Arts Initiative's social practice lab's "Write Sky" project. It was important for both organizations to have multilingual parts in the message (Chinese and Latin) that communicated the power and community necessity of education. "Scientia" means knowledge and 正义 means justice. Read more: www.writesky.com. #writesky

Today, Teacher Losang Samten completed his week-long residency with FACTS. Each year we are honored to have him in our school as he creates a mandala out of sand on a large table in our 3rd floor lobby. A mandala is a visual representation of a tantra, or, a body of beliefs and teachings. This year Teacher Losang constructed the Kalachakra Mandala, also known as “The Wheel of Time.”

The mandala depicts knowledge and understanding of all events and perceptions, past, present and future and is a vehicle for world peace. With their classroom teachers, FACTS students had the opportunity to sit with Teacher Losang as he constructed the mandala throughout the week. Students learned about different aspects of the art form, discussed issues of peace and conflict, and learned about Teacher Losang’s life.

Teacher Losang’s residency with FACTS ended today with a dismantling ceremony. The dismantling of the mandala serves an important purpose in acknowledging the impermanence of all aspects of life.
